title: 111_hr5461
content: The Act titled "Virtual Screening for Colorectal Cancer Act of 2010" covers screening computed tomography colonography as a colorectal cancer screening test under Medicare. The Act "Virtual Screening for Colorectal Cancer Act of 2010" includes screening computed tomography colonography as a colorectal cancer screening test under Medicare, with payment consistent with similar services. Payment for screening computed tomography colonography under Medicare shall not exceed the amount specified by the Secretary. Additionally, there are limitations on coinsurance for individuals receiving this screening test. The coinsurance for colorectal cancer screening tests under Medicare is capped at 25 percent of the fee schedule payment amount. There is a frequency limit for screening computed tomography colonography, with no payment allowed for individuals under 50 years of age or for high-risk individuals within 23 months of a previous procedure. The frequency limits for colorectal cancer screening tests under Medicare are outlined, with specific timeframes for screening computed tomography colonography based on the individual's risk level. The frequency limits for colorectal cancer screening tests under Medicare are amended to include screening computed tomography colonography, effective January 1, 2011. The Social Security Act is amended to include screening computed tomography colonography as a covered service under Medicare, effective January 1, 2011. Additionally, a report on the effectiveness of screening CTC in improving overall colorectal cancer compliance is required. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on the effectiveness of screening computed tomography colonography in improving colorectal cancer compliance. The study will assess the impact of screening CTC on Medicare beneficiaries' CRC screening compliance. The study will evaluate the utilization rates and referral rate of screening CTC for Medicare beneficiaries undergoing CRC screening. The study will assess the referral rate of screening CTC for Medicare beneficiaries, beneficiary preference for CRC screening options, access to screening CTC in rural or underserved areas, and other relevant issues. The Comptroller General will submit a preliminary report by March 1, 2015, and a final report by March 1, 2016. The Comptroller General will submit a final report to Congress by March 1, 2016, with recommendations for legislation and administrative action based on the study conducted on screening CTC for Medicare beneficiaries.
